subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Review charts for Shavian Quikscript Extensions
msgSnippet: ... As I see it, the main disagreement over shared code points has been whether to reuse encodings where the glyphs look and sound the same, or if (as you
messageBody:
I'd say the real questionable disunification is MIME and NUN from AH and AWE.

As I see it, the main disagreement over shared code points has been whether to reuse encodings where the glyphs look and sound the same, or if (as you suggest) simply looking the same is sufficient.  In the latter case, I have a practical question: what of computer-generated speech?  If there are new code points for AH and AWE, despite them having similar glyph shapes, then the pronunciation of the characters should be clear (our discussions of dialect notwithstanding); if they share code points I would imagine there would have to be a higher-level encoding which determines whether the computer is reading Shavian or QuickScript.  Would it be possible in that case to have both scripts on the same page?

oliver
